page.title: 01BY THE RIM OF THE OUSE BASIN
page.content: The block touches and includes all Helmdon. The corner of Sulgrave contains the Washingtons' manor-house and a loop of scattered houses. Helmdon slants across its valley, a mixture of its own fine grey limestone, imported and manufactured stone and brick. Only a few of its 700-odd prople work here, in farming, trade, small industries and building. Pasture overlies quarries and two railway lines which cross at a viaduct.The tove rises just to the north-west and is jointed by Helmdon's brook just to the east. Their valleys lie 360 to 550 feet above sea level. The soil is heavy and fertile, over oolite. Farms may average 240 acres, growing barley, wheat, rape and grass, and feeding dairy and beef cattle and sheep. Though some fields have been jointed, the landscape remains
